Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was double-checking the address label on a box of urgent medical supplies. It was Mia, my best friend, texting: “Ugh, today’s been endless. Can you talk?” I could almost hear the exhaustion in her words. I knew she needed me to listen, to be there for her, like I always tried to be. But the hospital was only fifteen minutes away, and traffic was unpredictable. The package in my hands wasn’t just any delivery—it was marked “urgent,” and I’d been told it was needed for a patient’s treatment. If I was late, it could mean real trouble for someone I’d never meet. My thumb hovered over my phone, torn between calling Mia to offer comfort and jumping in the van to beat the clock. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me—my friend needed my ear, but my job demanded my speed. My heart raced as I stood there, caught between the two worlds, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed at the same time.
